input text: Peter and the Piskies: Cornish Folk and Fairy Tales is a 1958 anthology of 34 fairy tales from Cornwall that have been collected and retold by Ruth Manning-Sanders and illustrated by Raymond Briggs.

prompts.system_prompt: You are an open IE extractor operating under a fixed ontology. From the text, propose triples [subject, relation, object] that satisfy the ontology’s domain→range. For every triple, cite exact supporting span(s) and give a 0–1 confidence. Output JSON only.
prompts.user_prompt:
Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"The Foundling and Other Tales of Prydain is a collection of short high fantasy stories for children by Lloyd Alexander and illustrator Margot Zemach."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["The Foundling and Other Tales of Prydain", "illustrator", "Margot Zemach"]]

NOTE:
- The example triples above are simplified bare triples.
- YOUR OUTPUT MUST follow the full schema described below
  (with subject_type, object_type, support, and confidence in [0,1]).
- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    Text
    "Peter and the Piskies: Cornish Folk and Fairy Tales is a 1958 anthology of 34 fairy tales from Cornwall that have been collected and retold by Ruth Manning-Sanders and illustrated by Raymond Briggs."

    Ontology concepts
    book, written work, literary work, human, author, publisher, International Standard Book Number, fictional character, literary genre, library, intellectual work, scientific journal, article, trade magazine, film, language, country, city, territory

    Ontology relations (domain → range)
    - title(book,monolingualtext)
- title(literary work,monolingualtext)
- author(book,human)
- author(literary work,human)
- editor(book,human)
- illustrator(book,human)
- publisher(book,publisher)
- printed by(book,publisher)
- publication date(book,time)
- place of publication(book,city)
- country of origin(book,country)
- language of work or name(book,language)
- genre(book,literary genre)
- narrative location(literary work,territory)
- characters(literary work,fictional character)
- follows(book,book)
- followed by(book,book)
- language of work or name(literary work,language)
- main subject(literary work,item)
- depicts(written work,item)
- author(written work,human)
- title(written work,monolingualtext)
- ISBN-13(book,string)
- ISBN-10(book,string)
- OCLC control number(book,string)
- Bibliothèque nationale de France ID(book,string)
- main subject(book,item)
- part of(book,literary work)
- based on(book,written work)
- soundtrack album(book,Q482994)
- production company(film,publisher)
- official website(book,string)
- Commons category(book,string)
- book title(book,monolingualtext)

    Constraints
    - Extract ALL clearly stated factual triples in the text (not just those that match ontology relations).
    - Do not discard a triple solely because it does not match any ontology relation; instead,
      assign the best-fitting subject_type and object_type concepts you can infer from the ontology.
    - For triples whose relation label appears in the ontology, respect the domain and range for subject_type and object_type.
    - Always extract any explicit date, time, or year mentioned in the text as part of a factual triple when relevant.
    - Resolve pronouns to the nearest valid antecedent if needed to form a correct triple.
    - Do not invent entities that are not mentioned in the text.
    - Output MUST be valid JSON and nothing else.

Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"It was followed by two sequels, Shadow of the Beast II in 1990 and Shadow of the Beast III in 1993."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["Shadow of the Beast", "followed_by", "Shadow of the Beast II"]]

NOTE:
- The example triples above are simplified bare triples.
- YOUR OUTPUT MUST follow the full schema described below
  (with subject_type, object_type, support, and confidence in [0,1]).
- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    Text
    "Two sequels were later created, Kessen II and Kessen III."

    Ontology concepts
    book, written work, literary work, human, author, publisher, International Standard Book Number, fictional character, literary genre, library, intellectual work, scientific journal, article, trade magazine, film, language, country, city, territory

    Ontology relations (domain → range)
    - title(book,monolingualtext)
- title(literary work,monolingualtext)
- author(book,human)
- author(literary work,human)
- editor(book,human)
- illustrator(book,human)
- publisher(book,publisher)
- printed by(book,publisher)
- publication date(book,time)
- place of publication(book,city)
- country of origin(book,country)
- language of work or name(book,language)
- genre(book,literary genre)
- narrative location(literary work,territory)
- characters(literary work,fictional character)

- followed by(book,book)
- language of work or name(literary work,language)

- depicts(written work,item)

- ISBN-10(book,string)
- OCLC control number(book,string)

    Constraints
    - Extract ALL clearly stated factual triples in the text (not just those that match ontology relations).
    - Do not discard a triple solely because it does not match any ontology relation; instead,
      assign the best-fitting subject_type and object_type concepts you can infer from the ontology.
    - For triples whose relation label appears in the ontology, respect the domain and range for subject_type and object_type.
    - Always extract any explicit date, time, or year mentioned in the text as part of a factual triple when relevant.
    - Resolve pronouns to the nearest valid antecedent if needed to form a correct triple.
    - Do not invent entities that are not mentioned in the text.
    - Output MUST be valid JSON and nothing else.

      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.

      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.

              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.

Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"An indirect sequel and reboot of the series, Armored Core 3, was released in 2002 for the PlayStation 2."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["Armored Core 2: Another Age", "followed_by", "Armored Core 3"]]

- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    book, written work, literary work, human, author, publisher, International Standard Book Number, fictional character, literary genre, library, intellectual work, scientific journal, article, trade magazine, film, language, country, city, territory

    - title(book,monolingualtext)

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"It was followed by two sequels, Shadow of the Beast II in 1990 and Shadow of the Beast III in 1993."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["Shadow of the Beast", "followed_by", "Shadow of the Beast II"]]

NOTE:
- The example triples above are simplified bare triples.
- YOUR OUTPUT MUST follow the full schema described below
  (with subject_type, object_type, support, and confidence in [0,1]).
- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    Text
    "The Sonic 3 cartridge can be attached to an adapter on the Sonic & Knuckles cartridge, creating a combined game, Sonic 3 & Knuckles."

    Ontology concepts
    book, written work, literary work, human, author, publisher, International Standard Book Number, fictional character, literary genre, library, intellectual work, scientific journal, article, trade magazine, film, language, country, city, territory

    Ontology relations (domain → range)
    - title(book,monolingualtext)
- title(literary work,monolingualtext)
- author(book,human)
- author(literary work,human)
- editor(book,human)
- illustrator(book,human)
- publisher(book,publisher)
- printed by(book,publisher)
- publication date(book,time)
- place of publication(book,city)
- country of origin(book,country)
- language of work or name(book,language)
- genre(book,literary genre)
- narrative location(literary work,territory)
- characters(literary work,fictional character)
- follows(book,book)
- followed by(book,book)
- language of work or name(literary work,language)
- main subject(literary work,item)
- depicts(written work,item)
- author(written work,human)
- title(written work,monolingualtext)
- ISBN-13(book,string)
- ISBN-10(book,string)
- OCLC control number(book,string)
- Bibliothèque nationale de France ID(book,string)
- main subject(book,item)
- part of(book,literary work)
- based on(book,written work)
- soundtrack album(book,Q482994)
- production company(film,publisher)
- official website(book,string)
- Commons category(book,string)
- book title(book,monolingualtext)

    Constraints
    - Extract ALL clearly stated factual triples in the text (not just those that match ontology relations).
    - Do not discard a triple solely because it does not match any ontology relation; instead,
      assign the best-fitting subject_type and object_type concepts you can infer from the ontology.
    - For triples whose relation label appears in the ontology, respect the domain and range for subject_type and object_type.
    - Always extract any explicit date, time, or year mentioned in the text as part of a factual triple when relevant.
    - Resolve pronouns to the nearest valid antecedent if needed to form a correct triple.
    - Do not invent entities that are not mentioned in the text.
    - Output MUST be valid JSON and nothing else.

input text: Set in an Iraqi village during the Iran-Iraq war, Scattered Crumbs critiques a totalitarian dictatorship through the stories of an impoverished peasant family.

prompts.system_prompt: You are an open IE extractor operating under a fixed ontology. From the text, propose triples [subject, relation, object] that satisfy the ontology’s domain→range. For every triple, cite exact supporting span(s) and give a 0–1 confidence. Output JSON only.
prompts.user_prompt:
Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
Example sentence:
"Kiss the Dust is a young adult historical fiction novel about a twelve-year-old Kurdish girl and her family's escape from Iraq over the border into Iran."

Example triples (bare triples just to show what facts should emerge):
[["Kiss the Dust", "narrative_location", "Iraq"]]

NOTE:
- The example triples above are simplified bare triples.
- YOUR OUTPUT MUST follow the full schema described below
  (with subject_type, object_type, support, and confidence in [0,1]).
- Do not copy the example text; extract from the actual Text section only.

    Text
    "Set in an Iraqi village during the Iran-Iraq war, Scattered Crumbs critiques a totalitarian dictatorship through the stories of an impoverished peasant family."

    Ontology concepts
    book, written work, literary work, human, author, publisher, International Standard Book Number, fictional character, literary genre, library, intellectual work, scientific journal, article, trade magazine, film, language, country, city, territory

    Ontology relations (domain → range)
    - title(book,monolingualtext)
- title(literary work,monolingualtext)
- author(book,human)
- author(literary work,human)
- editor(book,human)
- illustrator(book,human)
- publisher(book,publisher)
- printed by(book,publisher)
- publication date(book,time)
- place of publication(book,city)
- country of origin(book,country)
- language of work or name(book,language)
- genre(book,literary genre)
- narrative location(literary work,territory)
- characters(literary work,fictional character)
- follows(book,book)
- followed by(book,book)
- language of work or name(literary work,language)
- main subject(literary work,item)
- depicts(written work,item)
- author(written work,human)
- title(written work,monolingualtext)
- ISBN-13(book,string)
- ISBN-10(book,string)
- OCLC control number(book,string)
- Bibliothèque nationale de France ID(book,string)
- main subject(book,item)
- part of(book,literary work)
- based on(book,written work)
- soundtrack album(book,Q482994)
- production company(film,publisher)
- official website(book,string)
- Commons category(book,string)
- book title(book,monolingualtext)

    Constraints
    - Extract ALL clearly stated factual triples in the text (not just those that match ontology relations).
    - Do not discard a triple solely because it does not match any ontology relation; instead,
      assign the best-fitting subject_type and object_type concepts you can infer from the ontology.
    - For triples whose relation label appears in the ontology, respect the domain and range for subject_type and object_type.
    - Always extract any explicit date, time, or year mentioned in the text as part of a factual triple when relevant.
    - Resolve pronouns to the nearest valid antecedent if needed to form a correct triple.
    - Do not invent entities that are not mentioned in the text.
    - Output MUST be valid JSON and nothing else.

prompts.user_prompt:
Task: Extract up to k triples that are directly supported by the text. You may paraphrase, but you must quote the evidence substrings.

    Requirements
    - Extract triples [subject, relation, object] that are explicitly supported by the text.
    - For any triple that instantiates an ontology relation (i.e., its relation label appears in the ontology),
      enforce domain→range consistency: the subject_type must match the relation’s domain concept, and
      the object_type must match the relation’s range concept.
    - You may also output factual triples that do NOT correspond to any ontology relation; in that case,
      choose the most appropriate subject_type and object_type concept labels from the ontology, but do not discard the triple.
    - Return JSON only, with this schema
        {
          "triples": [
            {
              "triple": ["subject","relation","object"],
              "subject_type": "Concept",
              "object_type": "Concept",
              "support": "exact quote from text",
              "confidence": 0.0
            }
          ]
        }
    - The confidence must be a real value between 0 and 1, estimated by how clearly the text supports the triple,
      and how well subject_type and object_type match the ontology types.



One-shot EXAMPLE (for guidance; do not copy the text):
